25233.title: Two White Dots in the Air
25233.description: hanging polychrome mobile, sheet metal and steel wire.  Made up of two parts.
25233.credit_line: Gift from the Joseph Cantor Collection
rights: © Estate of Alexander Calder / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

extended_text.content:
During his lifetime, Alexander Calder was recognized as one of the most original American artists of the interwar and postwar years. As a sculptor, painter, illustrator, printmaker and designer, he combined elements of European modernism with a unique approach to form that was influenced by his early experiences as a mechanical engineer.

Calder’s major contribution to the history of modern sculpture was the mobile, a term coined by Marcel Duchamp. In this new art form, Calder made movement a crucial element, at first by working with motors and then by suspending his sculptures from the ceiling so that they would be set into motion by the movement of air. The mobiles synthesized Constructivist methods with biomorphic imagery related to Surrealism. Two White Dots in the Air is a classic example of this genre, in which abstract shapes that evoke forms from nature such as fins, wings, leaves, or cosmic bodies, are gracefully suspended from curving wires. As these forms shift and rotate in often unpredictable ways, the sculpture seems possessed of its own life.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

25233.current_location: Nicholas H. & Marguerite L. Noyes Gallery (K405)

24892.title: evening dress
24892.description: blouse, skirt, sash | tpo all in one piece with an elastic, collar extends out of the fabric with slashing, crossover V shape neckline with crossover V shaped skirt opening
24892.provenance: Halston Limited c/o Micheal Lichtenstien, New York; given to the IMA July 10, 1980.

extended_text.content:
Halston said, "I love the idea of a ruffle that seems to come from nothing. I like things that look sculptured and yet are soft." The period from late 1970s to early 1980s is known as Halston's ruffle period. In 1980 Women Wear Daily gave Halston a new nickname, "Mr. Ruffle."

In Halston's innovative construction technique, the ruffles and body of the garment were created from one piece of fabric. This softly draped blouse with cut-in-one ruffles was created by cutting several layers of ruffles in minimally graduated widths to create a soft fluttery look.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

24892.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

66241.title: Spanish Sculpture VI
66241.credit_line: Indianapolis Museum of Art, The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, a joint initiative of the Trustees of the Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection and the National Gallery of Art, with generous support of the National Endowment for the Arts and the Institute of Museum and Library Services
66241.provenance: Dorothy and Herbert Vogel, New York; given to the National Gallery of Art probably 1991-1992; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2008 through the national gift program The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, organized by the National Gallery of Art, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

extended_text.content: Drawing is a daily activity for Richard Tuttle, and while traveling he often draws in notebooks, as demonstrated in the Spanish Sculpture series. This group of works consists of watercolor and graphite drawings on bond paper, which he taped to sheets of ruled notebook paper and glued onto corrugated cardboard. The Spanish Sculpture series pays homage to Spanish sculptor Julio González (1876-1942), whose welded metal constructions’ use of line and form to create space motivated Tuttle’s own exploration on paper. Tuttle carefully considers the presentation of his drawings, and in the case of these works he has selected the exact dimensions of the matting and frames, as well as the specific configuration seen here.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

59009.title: dress for evening ensemble
59009.description: custom design beadwork and embroidery, cardigan jacket
59009.medium_support: synthetic fabric, silk chiffon, bugle beads

extended_text.content:
This long-sleeve cardigan jacket is worn with a silk chiffon double-layer halter top tied into a bow at the front. Straight-leg trousers, gathered into a wide elastic waistband, complete the ensemble.

The custom-designed beadwork features a swirling pattern, which is used throughout the main field. The bottom parts of the jacket and trousers are embroidered in a wave pattern.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

24540.title: Basement and Highway
24540.credit_line: Gift of Thanks from the Indianapolis Chapter of the Embroider's Guild of America

extended_text.content:
Artist’s Statement

In my embroidered pictures, glimpses of everyday life merge with fragments of memory. Sewing is a slow and deliberate process, in contrast to the fleeting moments that trigger each piece.

This work is inspired by the intimacy and symbolic intensity of badges and stitched emblems. Basement and Highway reflects my interest in the balance between the cryptic and the mundane and in the way that small details imply the larger world.

-Tom Lundberg
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

4169.title: Leaving First
4169.medium_support: polypropylene net | painted | screen printed | interwoven

extended_text.content:
Artist’s Statement

Space and light, aspects of environment most commonly associated with architecture, are also inherently significant in textiles, although we seldom consider them as such.

In the fall, when leaves are no longer captives of tress, they leave home for one glorious moment of freedom, in light and space.

-Gerhardt Knodel
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

4169.exhibit_history: Accession number was incorrect and reflected five parts instead of the actual four parts, as labeled by the artist.   | hardware stored in bin9 lv1 dimensions: 18 1/2 x 43 x 3 1/2 in.

extended_text.content:
Artist Statement

This piece started with definite ideas about place and time. My studio is next to a pine forest and between two lakes in Michigan. The time is winter. I like the fluidity that ikat makes possible. It evokes the patterns of reflections of the tall pines on the water and the ragged outlines of land and water or of land and sky. My weaving was woven in three panels and each presents different moods during three months. The red shapes are symbols for myself, for anchors, for ends and beginnings, like shoving off with a canoe to start a journey and meandering through different kinds of water and docking along various shores.

-Anneke Herrold
extended_text.title: Gallery Label
